This will need discussion. If only an owner or admin can do this, it's kinda pointless. On the other hand information can be leaked this way: Where the schema is located or that the assigned USER or ROLE exists.
Maybe limiting this to Owner/Admin is fine.
This would also need discussion. I'm using it only when retrieving schema info, not when creating a schema (to avoid changing many dozens of interfaces/classes)
See the comment... With this we can avoid adding a new method to each and every connector.
Let's iterate over io.prestosql.plugin.hive.HiveSchemaProperties#SCHEMA_PROPERTIES instead listing all properties here.

Not sure how I would that. Each property has a different source. So while I could loop, each value (like location here) has a different way to get the value, unless we generalize that and match it up with the Hive properties.
I would prefer to have two methods. One to get schema properties and one to schema owner. You may want to use io.prestosql.spi.connector.ConnectorMetadata#schemaExists to verify if schema exists.
I was trying to avoid polluting the interface even more, and the owner is kinda part of the definition of a schema. I don't feel strongly, though.
It needs to be filterSchema to filter out the information_schema and the "sys" schema. Schema existence is checked higher in the call stack and in addition the Database is an Optional.

How does SHOW CREATE TABLE work when user does not specify any property, are they still displayed?
I am concern about displaying locations. It looks like external_location is not displayed when it is not set to some custom value.

Schema is handled differently. The Hivemetastore sets the default, so it's always set. Without some bigger effort I cannot hide it if it is the Hive default.
Table location, on the other hand, is shown when the table's type is "external table", otherwise it isn't even set.

I think this condition is not enough. Is it possible that one could create external table under warehouse location? Like pointing to data of another managed table? I do think there is a check for that in Hive and this allowed. We need to verify full path, not only prefix.
Please add test for that.

The default is <warehouse.dir>/<schemaname>.db, but any path is allowed (without ending in .db). So I think we should verify <warehouse.dir>/<schemaname> exactly.
But people can vary the "extension" too. The file based hive metastore has no extensions.
So if you name your location <warehouse.dir>/<schemaname>.mydb should I show the location or not?
Also looks like there are no further checks. I can create a schema in /a/b/c and also in /a/b, then create a table t in /a/b. Now we have a schema c and table t in the same directory.
@kokosing

BTW. Hive always shows the location whether it's default or not.
Perhaps it's better to follow that?
hive> create database bla;
OK
Time taken: 0.884 seconds
hive> show create schema bla;
OK
CREATE DATABASE `bla`
LOCATION
  'hdfs://localhost:9000/user/hive/warehouse/bla.db'
Time taken: 0.048 seconds, Fetched: 3 row(s)

Also if user is allowed to do show create schema then we don't need to filter schema here.

This is for the information_schema and for Hive's sys schema.
(see listSchemas, listTables methods, etc.)
That is to say: information_schema and sys have no owner as such, and they also do not have any properties.

Please do not use filterSchema but just make sure that requested schema is one of these. And if it is the case I think we should throw an exception.
@findepi I think you are more familiar with sys schema. Are ok with my suggestion?

See #3099 (comment)
getSchemaOwner should look similar to getSchemaProperties

You should use io.prestosql.testing.AbstractTestQueryFramework#executeExclusively
provide reset() method that would reset all the custom configuration

I don't like this optionality. When you ask for properties of not existing object this method should fail. Returning empty map suggests that object exists but has no properties.
Same to the method below.
Hmm... I was following other examples such as getView and getTable. But these are different.
This is more like io.prestosql.metadata.MetadataManager#getTableProperties
Added an error check to both methods.
ImmutableMap
invert condition. Then else block is not needed.
I would you to use io.prestosql.plugin.hive.HiveSchemaProperties#SCHEMA_PROPERTIES. So whenever someone adds new schema property they don't need to do any changes here.

Not sure what you mean. I would still need to add custom code here for each property to retrieved. For example the location is read from the Database object. Other properties have other ways to be retrieved.
Can you explain what you mean? Apologies if I'm missing something obvious.
Do you mean add a method to HiveSchemaProperties that is being passed a Database object? Or more like HiveTableProperties?
I added method to HiveSchemaProperties. Lemme know what you think.

Please do not use filterSchema but just make sure that requested schema is one of these. And if it is the case I think we should throw an exception.
@findepi I think you are more familiar with sys schema. Are ok with my suggestion?

That's precisely what HiveMetadata.filterSchema does, though. It's a static method that checks for these schemas (I suppose it's badly named).
I can throw an exception instead, but I'd just do the same check with extra code.
Should I add a new error code to HiveErrorCode?
Have look. Throwing NOT_SUPPORTED exception now.

Can engine call getSchemaProperties without calling schemaExists first? (Does engine guarantee that?)

yes => sys needs to be filtered out; and we should return NOT_FOUND (because we pretend the "sys" schema does not exist, as indicated by false from schemaExists)
no => checkState would be more appropriate: checkState(filterSchema(..), "Schema is not accessible: %s", schemaName)

This is indeed only called from ShowQueriesRewrite,Visitor.visitShowCreate(...), which does check schemaExists first and throws SCHEMA_NOT_FOUND from there. (Although it's not guaranteed that nobody will add such a call in the future.)
Added checkState bit...
Do you still need it?
I thought it might not hurt to have it . Happy to remove it.

I would be happy too.
We typically do not leave things that are not used. Future is unpredictable, so let's avoid of being too smart.
I'll remove it.

the other day I left a comment to use assertj, it has some native support for regex matching. If you apply that comment then I would expect this code become very fluent and so we might have no longer a need for this method (we could just inline it).
assertMatch -> assertMatches
static. It does not belong to AbstractTestQueryFramework, but rather to something like PrestoAssert.
I think it should throw by default.
Hmm... Should SHOW CREATE SCHEMA fail on every connector except the Hive connector?
I suppose any connector that does not support schemas should - and safely - throw an exception.
I think it should throw by default.
Same here, should SHOW CREATE SCHEMA fail on every connector except the Hive connector?

Access control should be done on different level. If this method is called then you should  assume that user has access to this schema or it will be filtered later.
In other words, please remove this line.

We have discussed this above :) See @findepi 's comment. It's not access control.
This is only for the information_schema and sys. And those are not available for properties or ownership. These should never be triggered, since all callers check for schemaExists first, it's just a safety consistency check in case someone adds a call to this later.
I see, thanks!

Access control should be done on different level. If this method is called then you should  assume that user has access to this schema or it will be filtered later.
In other words, please remove this line.
See above :)
Is this correct? I guess RDBMS might have a notion of schema owner. Maybe we should leave it unimplemented?

Throw UnsupportedException?
What I did was to have an implementation that does not fail for every connector that supports CREATE SCHEMA. Wouldn't it be weird to have SHOW CREATE SCHEMA fail with an exception here?
No problem removing the implementation here, we have to just be aware of the implications.
I think we might add properties for schemas in the Jdbc Connector in the future. So getSchema  Owner (IMHO) should not fail.

Wouldn't it be weird to have SHOW CREATE SCHEMA fail with an exception here?

If it is better to fail than return incorrect data. In other words, JDBC connectors is a pandora box let's not open it for now.
Ok... Lemme do that.

Also... I assume the same holds for KuduMetadata, BlackHoleMetaData, MemoryMetadata, PhoenixMetadata?
The logic I followed was that if a connector has CREATE SCHEMA it should also not fail when doing SHOW CREATE SCHEMA even when there's no info to show.
Unless I hear otherwise from you I will remove all no-op implementation of these methods and have all those connectors fail when issuing SHOW CREATE SCHEMA.

BlackHoleMetaData and MemoryMetadata are trivial so you could implement that method for them.
I would skip rest for now.
Oh missed this. I will add this back for BlockHoleMetadata and MemoryMetadata.

We need also add simple test to io.prestosql.testing.AbstractTestIntegrationSmokeTest. That file is used to test connector implementations, you change connector SPI so we need tests for other connectors. It can be very simple, without any access control. Probably for most of the connectors it will be skipped.

I'm not sure what I would test.
It's kinda like TestHiveIntegrationSmokeTest.testSchemaOperations, which only exists in TestHiveIntegrationSmokeTest, because it doesn't make sense for many other connectors, and there's no equivalent for this test in the other connector tests.
I do not see any tests in there for features that are not supported in some connectors.
Do you have a suggestions about what I can test generally?

I was thinking to add simple SHOW CREATE SCHEMA tpch. If connector does not support this, then we could disable that test for this connector, but it will be known that there is a feature that given connector does not support.

I see. Makes sense.
Should probably pull TestHiveIntegrationSmokeTest.testSchemaOperations up to AbstractTestIntegrationSmokeTest as well then.
Edit: So I looked at it more. The only connectors that support this now are the HiveConnector and the IcebergConnector. So if I add a method to AbstractTestIntegrationSmokeTest all other connectors would just have an empty implementation, and Hive and Iceberg would have a slightly different implementation. So nothing gained :)
Makes sense
I think we should fail if schema does not exists
I think we should fail if schema does not exists
I think we should check existence of object before access control

See visitShowTables. It checks access first. It feels also generally better to check access first, otherwise you can "poke" the system (by trying schema names) and gain information you should not access to. Currently that might to be an issue with schema, but we might tighten visibility in the future.

invert the condition.
